blurb: The offensive line remains a huge question mark. No one argues that. But QB Russell Wilson is entering the prime of his career, and the defense should still be near the top of the NFL.
The Cardinals improved their biggest weakness from last season — the pass rush — and return an offense that should still be explosive as any in the league.
The Bengals have won at least 10 games each of the last four seasons but have lost in the wild-card round every year. They should be good again. But good enough to take the next step?
The Chiefs are a weird team in that you can convince yourself they'll go 9-7 just as easily as you can convince yourself they'll go 12-4. I'll go with somewhere in between.
The Raiders have become a trendy pick this season. Count me in on the bandwagon with Derek Carr and Amari Cooper.
The Colts have massive questions with the offensive line (sound familiar?) and with their pass rush. Can Andrew Luck make up for those holes?
A pivotal season for former Seahawks defensive coordinator Gus Bradley. He's never won more than five games in a season, but his team has enough talent to be better this year.
Former Seahawks receiver Golden Tate will have the chance to prove if he's a true No. 1 receiver after Calvin Johnson retired.
The Rams drafted QB Jared Goff No. 1 overall, but he won't even be in uniform during their first game because he's currently the third-string quarterback.
Anyone heard anything about Colin Kaepernick?
The Browns have won 10 games just once since 1999. That futility will live on at least another year.
Is Jimmy Garoppolo the next Tom Brady or Matt Cassel? He threw for 264 yards, one touchdown and completed 73 percent of his passes in his first start.
RB Thomas Rawls will start this week against the Rams, and that's good because the Seahawks need to get the running game going after struggling in week one.
A.J. Green: Still a monster. He had 12 catches and 180 yards against the Jets and famed cornerbak Darrelle Revis.
The Chiefs pulled off the largest comeback in team history — 21 points — to beat the Chargers.
WR Amari Cooper has played in 17 NFL games and already has six games with 100-plus yards.
Jets WR Brandon Marshall told Buffalo coach Rex Ryan he was going to "kick hiss butt" before Thursday night's game. Then he did.
QB Jameis Winston threw for four touchdowns and helped the Bucs make the biggest jump (along with Houston) from week one to week two.
It was against Cleveland, and it was just one game, but rookie Carson Wentz showed lots of promise in his first start: 278 yards, two touchdowns, no interceptions.
Shutouts in the NFL are super rare: There were just two in 2015. The 49ers held the Rams scoreless in the first game of the season.
The Bills fired offensive coordinator Greg Roman after just two games, and Rex Ryan's seat is scorching hot. Oh, and the Bills still haven't made the playoffs since 1999.
Jeff Fisher has said he doesn't want another 7-9 season, but after getting shut out in week one, he might take it.
Bill Belichick is amazing. He started his third-string quarterback — a rookie! — on a short week and still led his team to a 27-0 win.
The Cardinals lead the NFL with a plus-seven turnover ratio, and they still haven't turned the ball over this season.

RB Adrian Peterson had knee surgery and is out at least a few months, and DT Sharrif Floyd also had knee surgery this week. That's on top of losing QB Teddy Bridgewater to a knee injury before the season.
Since 2012, the Seahawks have been one of the NFL's most effective and successful running teams. After two weeks, the Seahawks rank 18th in rushing yards per game. That's got to change.
Packers QB Aaron Rodgers has gone 14 straight weeks without posting a passer rating of better than 100, which seems impossible.
Wait, which team was starting a rookie quarterback on Thursday night?
Rookie RB Ezekiel Elliott had a better week two: 83 yards on 21 carries. But he fumbled the ball twice and is averaging only 3.3 yards per carry through two games.
Chargers QB Philip Rivers just keeps on delivering. Through two games: 70 percent completion percentage, five touchdowns, no interceptions.
The Colts are 0-2 for the second straight season, and the defense allowed 39 points in week one and 34 points in week two.
The 49ers gave up 529 yards of total offense to the Panthers, who scored 46 points despite turning the ball over four times.
The Jaguars are 0-2 for the fourth time in five seasons, and history suggests that the vast majority of 0-2 teams don't make the playoffs.
The Vikings' defense is the reason Minnesota is off to a 3-0 start. Even with injuries across the board, the defense should keep Minnesota alive all season.
We'll find out against the Jets on Sunday if last week's rushing resurgence was truly a turning point or an aberration against a struggling 49ers team.
Rookie QB Carson Wentz gets the attention, but the Eagles' defense has allowed the fewest points in the league through three games.
Is it time to start worrying about Arizona? The Cardinals got blown out by the Bills and are 1-2 this season.
The Ravens have won their three games by a total of 13 points against three teams with a combined win total of one.
The Raiders lead the NFL averaging 5.9 yards per carry, and three Raiders have rushed for 100 yards already this season.
The Texans will be without star defensive tackle J.J. Watt until at least December, if not for the whole season. Houston's status as the NFC South's favorite just got murky.
Jets QB Ryan Fitzpatrick has thrown seven interceptions this season, including six last week. Will he give the Seahawks some chances to create turnovers down the field?
The Bills have the fewest passing yards in the league and are the worst offense on third down, and yet they just crushed Arizona. Go figure.
Seahawks defensive lineman Michael Bennett pretty accurately summed up the feelings of many when asked about the challenge of defending 49ers QB Blaine Gabbert: "There is no challenge."
The question surrounding former Seahawks defensive coordinator Gus Bradley: Will he survive his team's 0-3 start. He is 12-38 with the Jaguars.
Browns WR Terrelle Pryor told Cleveland.com he thinks the Browns can win out; Steelers RB DeAngelo Williams posted on Instragram, "Maybe he was talking about Ohio State."
Yes, New England got blown out by Buffalo, but it was without Tom Brady. And guess what? He just walked back through the door.
Russell Wilson averaged a career-high 30 passing attempts last season. He is averaging 34 attempts this season. Are the Seahawks shifting their offensive identity?
RB Le'Veon Bell didn't waste much time in reminding us all just how good he is: 144 rushing yards, 34 yards, a blowout win for the Steelers.
The good news: Oakland is seventh in the league in scoring offense and piles up yards. The bad news: Oakland in 22nd in the league in scoring defense and teams are piling up yards.
Former Seahawks defensive coordinator Dan Quinn's Falcons team was hit with the same practice violations as the Seahawks and will be docked three practices next spring.
Star RB Todd Gurley is averaging less than three yards per carry and Case Keenum is still the quarterback, so of course the Rams are 3-1. Right?
The Panthers haven't been able to rush the passer and can't protect their quarterback, and Cam Newton is hurt, and they're 1-3.
The Bills shut out the Patriots at home for the first time since before Pete Carroll was New England's head coach.
The Colts have allowed Andrew Luck to be sacked 15 times this season, the most in the NFL. Somehow, his pass protection actually seems worse.
Coach John Fox was pretty clear about where QB Jay Cutler stood: He said he won't the job back to Cutler when he returns from injury.
The Browns have started three quarterbacks this season, and they are the only winless team left in the league.
The Vikings are the only undefeated team left in the NFL and still the top defense in terms of fewest points allowed. Mike Zimmer has to lead the coach of the year race right now.
Tom Brady threw for 400 yards in his first game back. What rust? Said TE Martellus Bennett to reporters: "We got the WD-40 out there for him."
Can the Seahawks get the run game going? The Seahawks are 30th in yards per carry through five weeks.
Falcons QB Matt Ryan leads the NFL in passing yards, but just as dangerous is Atlanta's two-headed monster at running back.
Rookie QB Dak Prescott has the Cowboys 4-1, but there's a QB controvery brewing when Tony Romo returns. New Jersey Governor Chris Christie, for one, thinks Romo should play when he returns.
The Ravens fired their offensive coordinator, Marc Trestman, after another lackluster game. For some reason, Baltimore has gotten away from its run-the-ball identity.
The Bills have beaten the Cardinals and Rams and have the 49ers this week. Are they NFC West killers?
Hooray for rookie kicker Robert Aguayo, who missed two kicks Monday night before responding to hit the game-winner. It's not Aguayo's fault the Bucs drafted him in the 2nd round.
Colts GM Ryan Grigson said last week that Andrew Luck's massive contract made it hard to improve the defense, which didn't go over well with many people in Indianapolis.
The Panthers are 1-4. Declared one headline this week: What on earth happened to the Carolina Panthers?
The Jets are the 23rd ranked defense this season. Last year they ranked 9th.
Coach John Fox didn't like reporters questioning the decision-making of his quarterback. Said Fox of his QB: "It looks a little different than when you’re up in the press box having hot dogs."
Colin Kaepernick finally gets his chance to start. He can't do much worse than Blaine Gabbert.
Tom Brady is barely human. In his first two games back, Brady has completed 76 percent of his passes, thrown six touchdowns and had zero interceptions.
The Seahawks' defense (mostly) stood up to the test against the Falcons, but the running game is still an issue. The Seahawks rank 30th in yards per carry.
Heaven help anyone who has to play David Johnson in fantasy football. Last two games: five touchdowns, 268 rushing yards, 55 yards receiving.
Former NFL linebacker Bart Scott told CBS Sports Radio that he no longer thinks Aaron Rodgers is a top five QB.
Washington has won four straight games but still trail the Cowboys in the NFC East.
QB Brock Osweiler has struggled this season, but in the fourth quarter of last week's comeback against the Colts, Osweiler played more like his price tag.
Can we stop with the Odell Beckham Jr. hugging-the-net stuff?
All six of the Ravens' games this season have been decided by six points. They won the first three and have lost their last three.
It was just last year that Todd Gurley looked like a guy who could maybe change the NFC West. But he's still averaging less than three yards per carry.
Jay Ajayi rushed for 117 yards in his first four games this season. He rushed for 204 yards last week against the Steelers.
The Panthers let CB Josh Norman leave this offseason, and their secondary has been awful this season without him and other veterans.
Jets WR Brandon Marshall said teammate Geno Smith "punched adversity in the face." Smith, you may remember, was punched in the facy by a teammate.
The Patriots are 3-0 since Tom Brady's return, but the defense is also holding up its end of the bargain. New England ranks fourth in points allowed this season.
The Seahawks rank 23rd in the NFL with just two rushing plays of at least 20 yards. They ranked 9th last year and 3rd two years ago.
Aaron Rodgers broke a franchise record for completions. Yeah, yeah. He also wore the same sweater as The Dude from "The Big Lebowski," which is way more impressive.
The Eagles' defense continues to be stingy. They held the Vikings to just 10 points and are just a tick behind the Seahawks and Minnesota for fewest points allowed.
The Falcons blew a 27-10 lead against the Chargers and have now lost two close, crushing games in consecutive weeks.
Matthew Stafford as an MVP candidate? It's hard to see that happening, but the Detroit Free Press wrote about Stafford's improving odds this week. Either way, he's been really good this year.
The Chargers are easily the best 3-4 team in the league, and some pundits think the Chargers could actually win the AFC West.
Jay Ajayi rushed for 204 yards two weeks ago. Last week? He followed it up with 214 yards.
Jets QB Ryan Fitzpatrick called out his coach, his owner and his general manager for losing faith in him. But, hey, the Jets won last week!
The Saints struggle stopping the run on defense, which could be just the cure for Seattle's struggling rushing attack.
This offseason, Browns coach Hue Jackson took exception when former coach Brian Billick said Cleveland could go winless this season. Update: the Browns are 0-7.
The Patriots traded a quality linebacker, Jamie Collins, to Cleveland for a future draft pick. On the surface, but this being the Patriots, it's best to hold off judgment.
The Cowboys are clearly the best team in the NFC right now.
The Chiefs have won three straight games and have pushed themselves back into status as a contender.
The Seahawks' offense has scored just one touchdown in the last nine quarters. Something needs to change.
Offensive coordinator Norv Turner abrubtly resigned this week. A strange season in Minnesota gets stranger.
The Packers lost, but Aaron Rodgers threw four touchdowns and completed 74 percent of his passes working with receivers most people had never heard of.
The Texans are 5-3. But they are the only team ranked in the bottom 10 for turnover margin to still lead a division.
The Bills will be bringing a familiar face to Seattle this weekend: suddenly unretired receiver Percy Harvin. Interesting to see the reception he'll get from his former teammates.
Cam Newton vented his frustration for calls he doesn't think he's getting in games. Even asked to talk with commissioner Roger Goodell. Oh, and Newton's team picked up a rare win this year.
Ryan Fitzpatrick takes the blame for the Jets season and also gets ripped by former Jets QB Joe Namath. Interesting week in New York.
The Jaguars fired their offensive coordinator. More jobs could be lost in the coming weeks as Jacksonville continues to slide under former Seahawks' DC Gus Bradley.
Tom Brady has played in four games and thrown 134 passes. And he still hasn't thrown an interception. And he's 39.
Derek Carr is making a legit MVP case. He's on pace for more than 5,000 yards and has thrown 17 TDs to just three interceptions.
The Seahawks' offense hummed with a healthy Russell Wilson, Doug Baldwin and Jimmy Graham. One problem: The Seahawks still can't run the ball.
It feels wrong putting Houston this high, but the NFL is just filled with medicore teams this season, and this is a reflection of that.
Without Adrian Peterson, the Vikings are last in the league in yards per carry (2.7) and second-to-last in rushing yards per game.
Golden Tate TD celebrations ranked: 1. Bye-bye wave against the Rams. 2. Dive into the end zone last week for the game-winning touchdown.
The NFL should allow the Bills and Seahawks to play every year as long as Rex Ryan and Pete Carroll are still coaching.
The Eagles have lost four of five games and their once-stingy defense has allowed 23 points or more in all four losses.
Andrew Luck seemed so thrilled with the Colts win in Green Bay that I bet he'll read an extra book during the bye week.
The Rams have lost four straight games. Case Keenum, the team's starting quarterback, has thrown eight interceptions in that span. That is not great.
Reminder: Cleveland coach Hue Jackson scoffed at former NFL coach Brian Billick for saying the Browns could go winless this season. Update: Cleveland is 0-8.
Tony Romo on rookie quarterback Dak Prescott: "He's earned the right to be our quarterback." Pretty powerful statement from Romo.
Russell Wilson looks like he did in the second half of last season: sharp, crisp, able to scramble when he needs to. Oh, and he's completed 71 percent of his passes in his last two games.
Latavius Murray just gave the Raiders their first 100-yard rushing performance this season, which could be huge for an offense so reliant on Derek Carr.
It's still hard to believe in the Texans. Just look at Brock Osweiler's stat line from last week's win against Jacksonville: 27 attempts, 99 yards. Ugly.
The Falcons ranked 14th in points per game defensively under Dan Quinn in his first season. They rank 28th in points per game this year.
Something to watch for this Sunday: Seahawks coach Pete Carroll said the Eagles have the best special-teams unit of any team they've played this season.
Philip Rivers is probably a Hall of Fame quarterback, but he was terrible at the end of last week's loss against the Dolphins, throwing four painfully costly picks.
Remember when DeMarco Murray had one 100-yard game for the Eagles last season? He has five this week and is second in the NFL in rushing yards.
Packers coach Mike McCarthy wasn't bashful with reporters recently: "Let's state the facts: I'm a highly successful NFL coach."
Jared Goff will start for the Rams, which at least makes the end of the Rams' season a little interesting.
The Jets are floundering and still don't know who they'll play at quarterback: veteran Ryan Fitzpatrick or potential quarterback-of-the-future Bryce Petty.
The 49ers have the worst defense in the NFL.
Dak Prescott is a sensation on the field and legit MVP candidate...and yet everyone is talking about how he threw away a cup in the trash can?
The Seahawks are now the No. 1 scoring defense in the NFL, passing the Vikings this weekend. The Seahawks are trying to lead the league in fewest points allowed for the fifth straight season.
The Raiders have won four straight games for the first time since 2002, the last time they went to the Super Bowl. Just sayin'.
This is year four together for Andy Reid and QB Alex Smith and yet the Chiefs' offense still looks mediocre far too often.
The Lions are the first team in NFL history to have their first 10 games decided by seven points or fewer.
The Dolphins have won five straight games and look more and more like a legit playoff contender.
After a 1-3 start, QB Jameis Winston has been on a roll: 13 touchdowns and two interceptions in the last six games. A true test for the Seahawks' defense this week.
Watching Panthers LB Luke Kuechly leave with a concussion, then sobbing as he was carted off the field, was just gut-wrenching.
The Cardinals' defense has allowed 30 points in two of their three games since Arizona's 6-6 tie with the Seahawks.
The Packers have lost four straight games and five of their last season. During that stretch, they haven't had a player rush for more than 65 yards in a game.
Jeff Fisher needs to go 4-2 in the final six games this season to avoid his fifth straight season of seven wins or less.
The Jaguars are headed for their ninth consecutive losing season, and it only seems a matter of time until the team parts with coach Gus Bradley.
Cowboys RB Ezekiel Elliott is just off the pace of Eric Dickerson's rookie rushing record of 1,808 yards set in 1983.
The offensive line was the Seahawks' biggest question mark coming into the season, and at this point it remains the biggest question: Was the performance in Tampa more an aberration or the norm?
Come on, don't lie: You would have tried to kick the field goal, too.
The Lions have pulled off fourth-quarter comebacks in all seven of their victories. That can't be sustainable.
Bucs OL Demar Dotson on the Seahawks' defensive line: "Those guys talk, man. I don't think they're as tough as they talk."
Kirk Cousins has eight touchdowns and no interceptions in his last three games while averaging 362 passing yards per game.
The Packers snapped a four-game losing streak but face concerns about Aaron Rodgers' hamstring and Clay Matthews' shoulder.
Brock Osweiler might be the worst starting quarterback in the league. He's at least in the running.
Drew Brees leads the NFL in yards, attempts, completion percentage and touchdowns. Weird to say, but Brees has been underratedly superb this season.
The Panthers led the NFL in scoring offense on the way to the Super Bowl a year ago; this year, Cam Newton and the Panthers rank 10th.
So the biggest news around the Rams right now is a feud between former great Eric Dickerson and coach Jeff Fisher over some sideline passes.
The 49ers have lost 10 straight games for the first time in franchise history.
The Cowboys scored their fewest points of the season last week. Can they get back on track against the Giants, the only team to beat them this year?
Khalil Mack is the most fun defensive player in the league to watch right now.
The Seahawks still lead the NFL in fewest points allowed this season in their quest for their fifth-consecutive scoring title.
The Giants have the league's second-worst rushing attack, averaging just 77.5 yards per game this season.
The Steelers have won three straight games and play only one team over .500 in their final four games.
Dan Quinn's defense is allowing the most pass yards per game this season.

It feels like a lot of chatter this season has focused on Aaron Rodgers' struggles. And then you look at his numbers: seventh in passing yards, second in touchdowns and he's on pace for the most rushing yards in his career.
Just when Washington started to get some momentum, they lose back-to-back games and allow 31 points in each loss.
Andrew Luck had his highest completion percentage, highest QB rating and most touchdowns this season against the Jets.
ESPN had an interesting note on Cardinals RB David Johnson: His 408 passing routes this season are more than Brandon Marshall and Julio Jones.
Eagles QB Carson Wentz in his last three games: 59 percent completion percentage, three touchdowns, six interceptions.
The last couple weeks have been brutal for Rams coach Jeff Fisher. The latest head-scratcher: Fisher told reporters he didn't know general manager Les Snead had received a contract extensoin.

The Browns are making a good run to finish with the franchise's worst record since returning to Cleveland in 1999. The Browns won two games that year. They need to win three of their final four to beat that mark.
Is Tom Brady the most reliable superstar in the NFL? He has 22 touchdowns and two interceptions and is playing as well as he ever has.
The hard thing for Dak Prescott is that every time he struggles, everyone is going to ask if it's Tony Romo time. Fair to wonder if that wears on him.

Most concerning for the Seahawks: Two of Russell Wilson's worst games have happened in the last three weeks. His eight interceptions in the last three weeks is as many as he threw last season and more than the threw two years ago.
The Bucs have won five straight and their defense has played well.
Remember when everyone was freaking out about Aaron Rodgers?
Washington probably needs to win its final three games to make the playoffs.
Brock Osweiler has the Texans in first place and has as many touchdowns (14) as interceptions (14).
The AFC South has been bad the last two years, but what's amazing is that the Colts and Andrew Luck still can't win the division.
What's going on with Drew Brees? He has six interceptions and no touchdowns in his lat two games.
The Rams have the worst scoring offense in the NFL and have ranked in the bottom four in the NFL in three of the last four seasons.
The Browns have lost 16 games in a row and are going to be underdogs in each of their final three games.
Random fact: The Raiders are the most penalized team in the NFL (The Seahawks rank sixth).
The Seahawks trail the Patriots by just two points for the scoring defense title. Good news for Seahawks: They still have the 49ers on the schedule.
RB Devonta Freeman had his first 100-yard rushing game since week three and also had his first three-touchdown game of the season.
Ty Montgomery has been a nice threat for the Packers in the backfield this season, but he exploded for 162 yards and two touchdowns last week.
Are the Broncos falling apart? An NFL.com story reported that members of the offense and defense had to be separated in the locker room after Sunday's loss to New England.
The Texans will start Tom Savage over Brock Osweiler. Tom Savage!
Former Seahawks running back Robert Turbin had two touchdowns in the Colts' win last week, giving him six for the season.
Just when you wonder about Drew Brees, he throws for 389 yards and four touchdowns in a win. All is right.
Seahawls LB K.J. Wright said he would vote Cardinals RB David Johnson the NFL MVP this season.
The Eagles have lost five straight games and their defense has allowed at least 26 points in each loss.
The Jets are in shambles but in a familiar position: Once again, they head into the offseason wondering who their quarterback will be.

The Jaguars fired their coach — and former Seahawks defensive coordinator — Gus Bradley. The amazing stat being passed around: Bill Belichick could lose 16 games for the next 41 seasons and still have a better winner percentage than Bradley.
It doesn't really matter what the Chiefs did last week. What matters is that 346-pound defensive tackle Dontari Poe threw a touchdown pass.
The Raiders won their 12th game for the first time since 2000, but they also lost QB Derek Carr — and their playoff chances — to an injury.
Aaron Rodgers's season statistcally isn't that different than his 2014 MVP season: 65.5 percent completion percentage, 36 TD, 7 interceptions.
The Seahawks rank 22nd in the NFL in rushing yards per game, which is pretty amazing for a team that prides itself on running the ball.
The good news: In two games, QB Tom Savage has yet to throw an interception. The bad news: In two gamse, QB Tom Savage has yet to throw a touchdown.
The Broncos were eliminated from the playoffs, which means neither Super Bowl participant from last season will make the playoffs the following year for the first time since 2003.
Drew Brees has thrown at least 32 touchdowns in each of the last nine seasons.
The Buffalo Bills don't have a quarterback of the future, but they also don't appear to want Tyrod Taylor anymore.
The Vikings are 2-8 in their last 10 games. Another team that is 2-8 in its last 10 games: Chicago.
Here's to hoping Tom Coughlin gets the Jaguars job and returns us all to 1999.
The 49ers have the worst passing offense in the NFL. But hey! The 49ers won a game last week, snapping a franchise-record 13-game losing streak.
